# The `SchedBoundary` Class Reference

<DoxygenPage pluginConfig={pluginConfig}>

## Description {#details}

Each Scheduling boundary is associated with ready queues.

It tracks the current cycle in the direction of movement, and maintains the state of &quot;hazards&quot; and other interlocks at the current cycle.

Definition at line 841 of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/codegen/machinescheduler-h">MachineScheduler.h</a>.

### bumpNode() {#a6b1771cf492495f8f82727657c68e571}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>void SchedBoundary::bumpNode (<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/sunit">SUnit</a> &#42; SU)</>}>
Move the boundary of scheduled code by one <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/sunit">SUnit</a>.

### checkHazard() {#adb8558f52662b83fe081b34b1f31fb20}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>bool SchedBoundary::checkHazard (<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/sunit">SUnit</a> &#42; SU)</>}>
Does this SU have a hazard within the current instruction group.

The scheduler supports two modes of hazard recognition. The first is the <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/schedulehazardrecognizer">ScheduleHazardRecognizer</a> API. It is a fully general hazard recognizer that supports highly complicated in-order reservation tables (<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/scoreboardhazardrecognizer">ScoreboardHazardRecognizer</a>) and arbitrary target-specific logic.

The second is a streamlined mechanism that checks for hazards based on simple counters that the scheduler itself maintains. It explicitly checks for instruction dispatch limitations, including the number of micro-ops that can dispatch per cycle.

TODO: Also check whether the SU must start a new group.

Declaration at line <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/codegen/machinescheduler-h/#l01032">1032</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/codegen/machinescheduler-h">MachineScheduler.h</a>, definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/codegen/machinescheduler-cpp/#l02454">2454</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/codegen/machinescheduler-cpp">MachineScheduler.cpp</a>.
</MemberDefinition>

<ParametersList title="Parameters">

<ParametersListItem name="AcquireAtCycle">indicates the number of consecutive (non-pipelined) cycles at which the resource is aquired after issue (assuming no stalls).</ParametersListItem>
</ParametersList>

<SectionUser title="Returns">
the next cycle at which the instruction may execute without oversubscribing resources.
</SectionUser>

### getLatencyStallCycles() {#a4a674627365b72b17a9b2e0a99d40ce1}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>unsigned SchedBoundary::getLatencyStallCycles (<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/sunit">SUnit</a> &#42; SU)</>}>
Get the difference between the given <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/sunit">SUnit</a>&#39;s ready time and the current cycle.

Compute the stall cycles based on this <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/sunit">SUnit</a>&#39;s ready time.

Heuristics treat these &quot;soft stalls&quot; differently than the hard stall cycles based on CPU resources and computed by <a href="#adb8558f52662b83fe081b34b1f31fb20">checkHazard()</a>. A fully in-order model (MicroOpBufferSize==0) will not make use of this since instructions are not available for scheduling until they are ready. However, a weaker in-order model may use this for heuristics. For example, if a processor has in-order behavior when reading certain resources, this may come into play.

Declaration at line <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/codegen/machinescheduler-h/#l01016">1016</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/codegen/machinescheduler-h">MachineScheduler.h</a>, definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/codegen/machinescheduler-cpp/#l02335">2335</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/codegen/machinescheduler-cpp">MachineScheduler.cpp</a>.
</MemberDefinition>

### pickOnlyChoice() {#a744d69baffaf2903667eb65cf07a6814}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>SUnit &#42; SchedBoundary::pickOnlyChoice ()</>}>
Call this before applying any other heuristics to the Available queue.

If this queue only has one ready candidate, return it.

Updates the Available/Pending Q&#39;s if necessary and returns the single available instruction, or NULL if there are multiple candidates.

As a side effect, defer any nodes that now hit a hazard, and advance the cycle until at least one node is ready. If multiple instructions are ready, return NULL.

Declaration at line <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/codegen/machinescheduler-h/#l01066">1066</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/codegen/machinescheduler-h">MachineScheduler.h</a>, definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/codegen/machinescheduler-cpp/#l02879">2879</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/codegen/machinescheduler-cpp">MachineScheduler.cpp</a>.
</MemberDefinition>

### releaseNode() {#a751090565ab555f2738aec07bc1a350c}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>void SchedBoundary::releaseNode (<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/sunit">SUnit</a> &#42; SU, unsigned ReadyCycle, bool InPQueue, unsigned Idx=0)</>}>
Release SU to make it ready.

If it&#39;s not in hazard, remove it from pending queue (if already in) and push into available queue. Otherwise, push the SU into pending queue.


<ParametersList title="Parameters">
<ParametersListItem name="SU">The unit to be released.</ParametersListItem>
<ParametersListItem name="ReadyCycle">Until which cycle the unit is ready.</ParametersListItem>
<ParametersListItem name="InPQueue">Whether SU is already in pending queue.</ParametersListItem>
<ParametersListItem name="Idx">Position offset in pending queue (if in it).</ParametersListItem>
</ParametersList>

### CurrCycle {#a370b818f3bb1f36ec91caf31cc95dbd9}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype="unsigned llvm::SchedBoundary::CurrCycle">
Number of cycles it takes to issue the instructions scheduled in this zone.

It is defined as: scheduled-micro-ops / issue-width + stalls. See getStalls().

Definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/codegen/machinescheduler-h/#l00867">867</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/codegen/machinescheduler-h">MachineScheduler.h</a>.
</MemberDefinition>

### ReservedCyclesIndex {#ae0e3134959c28004f015b8f031464263}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>SmallVector&lt;unsigned, 16&gt; llvm::SchedBoundary::ReservedCyclesIndex</>}>
For each PIdx, stores first index into ReservedResourceSegments that corresponds to it.

For example, consider the following 3 resources (ResourceCount = 3):

+---------—+-----—+ |ResourceName|NumUnits| +---------—+-----—+ | X | 2 | +---------—+-----—+ | Y | 3 | +---------—+-----—+ | Z | 1 | +---------—+-----—+

In this case, the total number of resource instances is 6. The vector ReservedResourceSegments will have a slot for each instance. The vector ReservedCyclesIndex will track at what index the first instance of the resource is found in the vector of ReservedResourceSegments: <CodeBlock>                         Indexes of instances in
                         ReservedResourceSegments

                         0   1   2   3   4  5
</CodeBlock> ReservedCyclesIndex&#91;0&#93; = 0; &#91;X0, X1, ReservedCyclesIndex&#91;1&#93; = 2; Y0, Y1, Y2 ReservedCyclesIndex&#91;2&#93; = 5; Z

Definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/codegen/machinescheduler-h/#l00938">938</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/codegen/machinescheduler-h">MachineScheduler.h</a>.
</MemberDefinition>

### ReservedResourceSegments {#a30ba79cae0c4a51e6e1b4b7fb83705e3}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>std::map&lt;unsigned, ResourceSegments&gt; llvm::SchedBoundary::ReservedResourceSegments</>}>
<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/record">Record</a> how resources have been allocated across the cycles of the execution.

Definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/codegen/machinescheduler-h/#l00907">907</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/codegen/machinescheduler-h">MachineScheduler.h</a>.
</MemberDefinition>
